body: Updating according to the latest comments. I will merge when Jenkins will be happy ;)

I tested this by patching the change internally on the local runner. 

Jenkins: run PythonPostCimmt
We should get some public coverage. Anyhow if any job at all, like an example E2E then I am satisfied. And TBH if it doesn't break the build again LGTM.

Isn't this a backwards incompatible change?

The 2.3.0 release candidate has these typos.

Yes, but the SpannerIO is marked Experimental.

From beam/sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/annotations/Experimental.java:
```
 * Signifies that a public API (public class, method or field) is subject to incompatible changes,
 * or even removal, in a future release.
```

Yeap, I think it's fine to get this in since it's experimental.

cc: @mairbek

Hi @cclauss, I looked at the errors and filed a few JIRA issues. Thank you for doing this, I believe we need to resolve the following issues to unblock this PR:

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-3669 - lint error most likely unrelated to your change.
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-3670 - test error, potentially affecting head.
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-3671 - jenkins machines are missing python3 binaries, may take a while to resolve.
Normally I would be fine with this as a workaround, but in this case I think you are right that it will mask problems that affect users.
Agree, but in that case we should mark [BEAM-3519](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-3519) as critical and eventually blocker. But I don't really know how easy would be to fix that one.
It was already "critical" but had no assignee and I think no one looked at it. I made it a "blocker" to make sure that we discuss the whole problem.
Read over https://beam.apache.org/contribute/ptransform-style-guide/ and see if it makes you think of anything. Also @jkff can you take a peek as author of that?
Should be fixed now, sorry about that.
Ah, missed the experimental annotation. Anyways, if you want you could ask to get this cherry picked into the 2.3.0 RC since it's likely that another 2.3.0 RC will be released.

a) yes.
b) both developers and users would do the same while building a Beam app: 
  * Along with beam-kafkaio dependency, they would include a specific version of kafka-clients library (e.g. kafka-clients version 0.9.0.1), and force the version in their dependency, or
  * Include specific version kafka-client library in their fat jar or set of jars at runtime.

I thought we had moved kafka-clients dependency in Beam to 'provided' scope. That way it is always the user who decides which version to include at runtime. Looks like it is not case, I will look into it. Moving the dependency to provided is good signal that KafkaIO supports multiple versions at runtime.

If developers are allowed to included a kafka-client 0.9, methods like `rawRecord.timestamp()` and `consumer.offsetsForTimes()` would fail to compile. Suppose kafka-client 0.10 is backward compatible(to access Kafka server 0.9*), I would suggest to not support kafka-client 0.9.

@lukecwik what is the plan to upgrade gcp client libraries? there are many important fixes in later versions (currently we need authenticated proxy support in the spanner client, this necessitates grpc >= 1.5) and it is not currently possible to pull in a new version of one library (spanner + associated dependencies) without upgrading the entire suite.

with the recently published [gcp bom](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/google-cloud-java/tree/master/google-cloud-bom) it is fairly easy to pull in the correct set of netty/grpc/etc dependencies for gcp. publishing a beam bom would reduce the amount of pain required to get a functioning set of dependencies in user jobs. shading is still necessary (thanks at least to netty) but it's much less painful than trying to find the magic version intersection that lets spark or flink use pubsub and spanner... assuming one exists.
I am closing this 'hack' in favor of the proper fix, however I had to do a new PR to remove this hack in other parts (I had already done the same in other ocurrences of the profile).

Yes, I believe this works correctly with watermarking. It will not work with fault-tolerance, though, because of a very peculiar "feature" of Flink: if any of the operators of a topology shut down checkpointing will not work anymore. However, in practice this is not a problem since sources of a streaming topology are not supposed to shut down so we will never come to `close()` in real-world use cases.

The issue this PR fixes only comes up in tests because we have bounded sources in a streaming pipeline, meaning we actually see a `close()` happening.

Also, there are two operators in Flink that follow the same pattern: 
 - https://github.com/apache/flink/blob/6593e0f9e6db9d862afadeeae79e0afa2590fd73/flink-streaming-java/src/main/java/org/apache/flink/streaming/api/operators/async/AsyncWaitOperator.java#L275
 - https://github.com/apache/flink/blob/8119baaf1bd5f22a6fd14909b61f01c644b62a66/flink-streaming-java/src/main/java/org/apache/flink/streaming/api/functions/source/ContinuousFileReaderOperator.java#L196

I'm not saying that I like this, to be honest, I'm just saying that this is the way we currently have to do it.
gradle build is fixed now. Waiting Jenkins to merge.
Curiously, I'm not seeing a lot of the logging that I get locally - in particular on the cmdline I definitely see messages about which deps are cached and which are fetched. Hmm.
@cclauss I do not know the status of this PR. How about we first address issues with running flake8 with python2? Once those are resolved, we can target the python3 related issues.

Once #4561 lands, the codebase will pass:
* __python2 -m flake8 . --count --select=E901,E999,F821,F822,F823 --show-source --statistics__
+1 to the provided change, sorry to came late to the review, I will take a look once this is changed to validate that everything works as expected with version 0.9.0.1
(Currently built on #4575, will rebase when that goes in; the last commit is reviewable, though)

@XuMingmin, you are right. Those methods won't compile, that's why we don't support buiding KafkaIO with 0.9.x. But it is fine at runtime since those methods are not called if the version 0.9x. If the user uses 0.10.x to talk to 0.9.x servers, then it is fine. We just don't want to force users to use 0.10.1+ (@iemejia & @jbonofre commented about it on user@ thread).
I will move the dependency to provided scope.

Have you confirmed that the seed job has run and updated what gets called?

If this doesn't work, revert it?
It definitely works to get more info, just not all the info seemingly.

No plan has been formulated, only a request to perform an upgrade of the gRPC libraries (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-3098).

It would be best to have this discussion on the Apache Beam dev@ mailing list to see what the community wants so that a plan can be formulated and someone who owns funding the effort. A plan which improves the world for only one runner at the expense of the other runners is unlikely to gain traction.
@chamikaramj The latest java presubmit was successful. Can you merge this when you get a chance? Thanks!

Thanks @XuMingmin.
@iemejia can you +1 'provided' scope change? Should we update any documentation? This essentially requires users to update their dependencies to include kafka-clients.

@herohde Please have a look. I have updated the PR to include the boot.go changes. However I am not sure how the actual id is passed to the boot.go as a flag. I made similar change in internal version of boot.go and using the new worker image.

Nice. I think this is really important.

*[sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/impl/rel/BeamJoinRel.java, line 213 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4642#-L4wbB3I-RJkArBkd8Wl:-L4wbB3I-RJkArBkd8Wm:b-e05f15) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/eeba1dd4078f329e2b60e902f71c590c993df34a/sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/impl/rel/BeamJoinRel.java#L213)):*
> ```Java
>         && !triggersOncePerWindow(windowingStrategy)) {
>       throw new UnsupportedOperationException(
>           "Joining unbounded PCollections is currently only supported for "
> ```

Actually the name of the method would be a good first sentence here: "... is currently only supported for triggers that outputs once per window, such as the default trigger with zero allowed lateness."

Let's leave off "`AfterWatermark.pastEndOfWindow()` with any lateness" because that encourages users to use a kind of trigger that is confusing and drops data.

---

*[sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/impl/rel/BeamJoinRel.java, line 228 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4642#-L4wba_bwmdi0F2NjrPq:-L4wba_bwmdi0F2NjrPr:bbsltu2) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/eeba1dd4078f329e2b60e902f71c590c993df34a/sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/impl/rel/BeamJoinRel.java#L228)):*
> ```Java
>     }
> 
>     return AfterWatermark.pastEndOfWindow().equals(trigger)
> ```

Actually let's also reject this just because it is a bad idea to use it anyhow unless allowed lateness is zero (and then you might as well be using the default trigger). Does it come in as a continuation trigger or something?

*[sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/test/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/BeamSqlDslJoinTest.java, line 258 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4642#-L4wc-O08uJmU9R9QPXa:-L4wc-O08uJmU9R9QPXb:brmw946) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/eeba1dd4078f329e2b60e902f71c590c993df34a/sdks/java/extensions/sql/src/test/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/extensions/sql/BeamSqlDslJoinTest.java#L258)):*
> ```Java
>     PCollectionTuple inputs = tuple("ORDER_DETAILS1", orders, "ORDER_DETAILS2", orders);
> 
>     thrown.expectCause(isA(UnsupportedOperationException.class));
> ```

Let's add one or two `expectMessage` checks here to make sure the most important words or phrases show up. Not the whole error message because that test is too fragile. But just to make sure it isn't some unrelated exception masking it. Same below.

Question on that - currently `SdkHarnessClient` closes the `FnApiControlClient`. I'm not sure it should do that since it is injected and I think it is reasonable that an `InstructionRequestHandler` could be safe for multiple users. More pragmatically, it largely exists to inject a lambda for testing. Ownership should be made utterly explicit either way. So in current revision I removed that.
Can this replace the maven Golang precommit? Currently still running.
The idea is that it'll replace the maven Go precommit. I just want to run them both for a few weeks before doing do.
R: @reuvenlax @kennknowles take a look if something like this aligns with schema-aware `PCollections`
Made changes based on the review, @lukecwik , PTAL?

Ah, ok. Well regardless adding the suppression should at least be done in a different PR, so I just squashed the commits into one that only changes the comment in findbugs-filter.xml. Since it's only a comment change I think even if some of the tests fail at this point this should get merged.

> if any of the operators of a topology shut down checkpointing will not work anymore

Ouch, that is very unfortunate, and means that Flink will not be able to fault-tolerantly run an SDF (or a stateful/timerful DoFn, for that matter) which runs forever per element (e.g. reading from Kafka). This *is* the intended use case of SDF: e.g. to read 1 Kafka topic, create a "bounded" source containing 1 element (name of the topic), followed by an SDF that reads kafka topics. The "bounded source" emits the single element and immediately completes, but the SDF runs perpetually.

This on its own might seem silly ("why not express reading from Kafka as a root operator?"), but SDF affords the flexibility that you now can also easily read a collection of Kafka topics, bounded or not (e.g. receive over a Kafka topic a stream of names of new Kafka topics to read). Or more interestingly: you can create a "bounded" source containing a set of filepatterns, and apply to it two SDFs: one (filepattern -> new files as they appear), the other (file -> new records as the file grows).

It also seems problematic that close() is rarely exercised in Flink pipelines. That means that this codepath is probably buggy in ways we don't know, it would be awkward if it started playing a central role in most streaming pipelines as the various unbounded sources are transitioned to SDF.

Am I understanding correctly that, if the upstream operators didn't terminate, then you wouldn't need to put the processing into close()? Maybe that's the way to fix this - have Flink in streaming mode treat bounded sources as unbounded, in the sense that once they emit their elements, instead of terminating, they just hang forever pretending that they might have more data?
I'm working on a proper fix "https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/4651" but it might take some time due to complexities in shading netty library. Can we proceed the release with this fix ?

PTAL.
Docker image no longer depends on conda, as new HDFS client is written in pure Python.
If the windowing strategy is propagated, why do you also need to indicate merging vs not?
No objections, of course, assuming it is a quirk of Dataflow. Just seems redundant.
The Dataflow worker can look at the windowing strategy but the service does not and it needs this piece of information for optimization reasons.
Filter*Stream are vicious cause buggy on some systems and a source of bottleneck is not fully delegated/reimplemented. Not the best we can offer to the users OOTB.
